body: Which output are you interested in?
The output of commands such as: ls and lsd
That would be relatively easy. Fancy giving it a go?
I had a look before created this request and I kind of got lost in the code. Care to point me in the right direction?

In fs/operations.go examine the ListLong function.

You'd want to write a variant of that and call it from cmd/ls/ls.go when a --json flag is set.

Something like that!

After a few hours of playing with this, it looks to be a little beyond my skill set. As rows are currently being printed as needed to the console, there isn't a definitive array of values to get. There would need to be a way to collect all of the rows from the data source, then the array can be converted to JSON.

@Wundark 
I would encode each line at a time, so at the start print a `[` then encode each line then print a `]` at the end.

issue.title: Add --json flag to return JSON for output listing

issue.body:
I am useless at GIT, but I have added the functionality to use the **--json** flag to return JSON for output listing

https://github.com/ncw/rclone/issues/1063

issue.title: Add --json flag to return JSON for file and directory lists

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body: I have created this from the following issue. https://github.com/ncw/rclone/issues/1063

body: This feature would be really helpful for me. I use rclone from PowerShell a lot and have to manually parse the output. But if rclone had --json I could do something like `$fileList = rclone ls remote: | ConvertFrom-Json`

@ncw 

>  I would encode each line at a time, so at the start print a [ then encode each line then print a ] at the end.

May i suggest to do a json stream with one json object per line.

Doing so the client reader does not need to wait until the end of the backup to interpret the json feed.

 So given that output, (-vv)

```
2017/03/11 12:59:34 INFO  : 
Transferred:   7.328 MBytes (62.472 MBytes/s)
Errors:                 0
Checks:                 0
Transferred:            0
Elapsed time:       100ms
Transferring:
 * "file1": 86% done, 0 Bytes/s, ETA: -
 * "file2": 21% done, 0 Bytes/s, ETA: -
 * "file3": 14% done, 0 Bytes/s, ETA: -
 * "file4": 11% done, 0 Bytes/s, ETA: -

2017/03/11 12:59:34 INFO  : file1: Copied (new)
2017/03/11 12:59:34 INFO  : folder2/some/other/emptyfile2: Copied (new)
```

Rclone would return three objects,
```json
{...stats}
{copied + new + path}
{copied + new + path}
```
@mh-cbon interesting idea.  That is a whole new level of JSON-ness - I've interpreted this issue as being about just having a version of ls which outputs JSON

really interested in using this feature as currently the output of ls is a bit difficult to parse into a mysql db because there seems to be no way to specify the desired formatting from ls so it just seperates by space, but weirdly the first field which is the filesize in bites is center aligned when piping out to a text file?

is there a work-in-progress version of this json output? Or is there any other way to tell the rclone ls command what type of formatting is desired? EG comma separated at the least?

Would be great to be able to output the dates and mime type as well!

Looking forward to using this as it would help with using a better advanced search system than the joke-of-a-search that is currently implemented on dropbox

issue.title: Owncloud support

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body: It would be great if owncloud would be natively supported.

body:
I've implemented a new command lsjson in this beta - let me know what you think.

https://beta.rclone.org/v1.36-185-g64662bef/ (uploaded in 15-30 imins)

This is fantastic, thank you! Now I can `rclone lsjson | ConvertFrom-Json` in PowerShell to really easily work with GDrive in PS!

Soon I'll be able to throw away my terrible PowerShell rclone parsing code :)
